author: Teresa Ramsey
title: Ongoing burglaries close Re-cycle charity group in Thames
text:
Dad jailed for suffocating his toddler daughter Ongoing burglaries close Re-cycle charity group in Thames TERESA RAMSEY Last updated 12:43, February 22 2017 Teresa Ramsey/Stuff.co.nz 
The Re-cycle group is now closing after ongoing thefts of bikes, parts and tools. 
A Thames group that recycles bikes for needy children is being forced to close its doors after ongoing burglaries. 
Since the Re-cycle group started four years ago, it has up-cycled more than 500 bikes and donated them to needy children in the Thames and Hauraki districts. 
However, in the past six months, ongoing burglaries and property damage at their Beach Rd site has meant they can no longer operate. TERESA RAMSEY/FAIRFAX NZ 
Re-cycle members, from left: Garry Leather, Eric Comer, Arthur Harsant and Chris Dale with some of the bikes left after the most recent burglary this week. 
Re-cycle group member Arthur Harsant said when members meet each week to up-cycle the bikes, they are met with another theft and more destruction of property. 
READ MORE: Karangahake school community devastated by theft of 22 Chromebooks 
Thieves have repeatedly cut through the wire fence, ransacked the property and on one occasion lit a fire. 
In the past few weeks, more than 50 up-cycled bikes have been taken, along with bike parts such as chains, wheels and cables that were needed to fix more bikes. 
"Literally pretty much all the bikes we've done up ready to give away in the last few weeks," he said. 
"We thought because of what we were doing, we'd be immune to this." 
Member Chris Dale said the last lot of stolen bikes were bound for children at Moanataiari School in Thames. Ad Feedback 
"The sad part is that if they want something, they just have to ask, we'll even help them build it," he said. 
The Re-cycle group was the legacy of late Thames Lawyer Bruce Oliver, who died shortly after setting it up. 
"He wanted to see everybody on a bike," Dale said. 
Bikes are donated from members of the public and Smart Environmental Refuse Transfer Stations around the Coromandel Peninsula. 
Once up-cycled, the bikes are donated to children whose parents can't afford to buy them a bike. 
Some are donated to adults who have just found employment but need transport to get to work. 
Group members also spend time in schools helping children rebuild bikes, which they get to take home. 
"The people that are stealing from here are actually stealing from the neediest section of the community, they are not stealing from the rich." 
Dale said attempts to report the thefts to police had been futile. 
However, group members were "down but not out", with plans to re-establish the group at the more secure Seagull Centre sometime this year. 
Members of the public can still donate old bikes to the group: Chris Dale, phone 07 868 2690, or Arthur Harsant, phone 07 868 9257. - Stuff
